As the publisher of Hippocrene Books, I would like to respond to Thomas Swick's essay on travel guides ("A Guide to Guidebooks for Who You Are, Not Where You're Going," July 4). Mr. Swick wrote that Hippocrene's "Polish Heritage Travel Guide to U.S.A. and Canada" "can be of little interest to anyone other than Polish-Americans."

It certainly is true that Polish-Americans, over 10 million strong according to the latest census, are very much the prime audience for this compilation of 195 Polish landmarks in North America. It was and is our hope that all Americans will be interested in what the Poles contributed to the common American heritage, much the way that other Hippocrene books in this series ("Guide to Black America," "Guide to Black Washington," "Guide to the Historic Black South," "Guide to Historic Hispanic America") have attracted the attention of those who find the ethnic diversity of our nation a source of our strength. JACEK GALAZKA New York
